titleStmt.title: Description of University of Pennsylvania Ms. Codex 597: Vita, morte e miracoli di Bartolomeo Garosi detto Brandano e volgarmente detto il Pazzo di Gesù Christo ... etc.

notesStmt.note: Titles and notes in pencil on f. i recto are in the hand of Henry Charles Lea, as is the note laid in between p. 62-63.

msIdentifier.repository: Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts

msContents.summary: Three biographies written in one hand. The first is of Bartolomeo Carosi, or Garosi, born ca. 1488 in Petroio (in this account Pretoria), province of Siena. Known as Brandano, "the madman of Jesus Christ," he was one of the itinerant apocalyptic preachers or "romiti" who flourished in Italy around the time of the Sack of Rome. This biography describes in detail his conversion, his devotions, his preaching activities, his miracles, and, in particular, the political bent soon taken on by his preaching: it claims that Brandano's influence on the popular classes was a significant factor in the Sienese revolt against the Spanish garrison in 1552. There is a different life of Brandano in UPenn Ms. Codex 287 (f. 49-98). The second biography is of Cecco d'Ascoli, an astrologer executed for heresy by the Inquisition in Florence in 1328 (according to this text--other sources give 1327 as his death date). The third biography describes the death of Giuliano de' Medici, younger brother of Lorenzo il Magnifico, killed during the Pazzi conspiracy in 1478 (incorrectly transcribed in Zacour-Hirsch as 1470).

msItem.title: Vita, morte e miracoli di Bartolomeo Garosi detto Brandano e volgarmente detto il Pazzo di Gesù Christo ... etc.

supportDesc.extent: 77 leaves : 214 x 161 (189 x 147) mm. bound to 221 x 163 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Paper, 77; [ii, 1-152]; modern pagination in pencil, upper right recto; p. 65-152 blank; final folio torn out.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Written in a cursive script by a single hand.

binding.p: Contemporary vellum, with some patches of vellum missing on upper cover.

history.provenance: Formerly owned by Henry Charles Lea, 1886 (bookplate, inside upper cover).
